Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Seasonal Phenotypic Flexibility in Passerine Birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Small birds adjust their physiology to cope with seasonal periods of high energy demands, but the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying these adjustments are poorly understood. One example of a period of high energy demand is cold winter climates, which promote increases in heat production capacity and cold tolerance in small birds, and this model forms the focus of this study. In this project, two prominent adjustments of small birds to seasonal periods of high energy demand will be investigated. An increase in the size of the flight muscles, which is associated with an increase the capacity for shivering heat production, and an increase in the capacity for muscles to use fat as fuel, are regulated at the cellular and molecular levels. Biochemical and molecular approaches will be used to characterize adjustments in key potential regulatory points in pathways controlling muscle growth and fat use. These studies will focus on myostatin, a prominent regulator of muscle size in mammals and birds, and proteins involved in transporting fat into and within the muscle cell. Changes in the levels of myostatin and fat transporters will be correlated with periods of high energy demand and elevated capacities for muscular heat production. These experiments will also distinguish the relative roles of temperature and day-length in driving seasonal adjustments in muscle size and fat use. These studies will markedly improve understanding of:

(1) the physiological mechanisms by which small birds respond to seasonal changes in energy demand;

(2) how environmental cues function as signals for physiological adjustments; and

(3) the capacity of small birds, and animals in general, to adjust physiology in response to changing climates.

The project will provide research opportunities and training for a postdoctoral fellow, a Ph.D. student, and several undergraduate students. Plans are in place to recruit Native American students to participate in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to better understand how small birds adjust their physiology to meet changing climates and changing energy demands. This is a critical issue in an age of global climate change and the data from this study will help inform predictions for how birds might respond to changing climates. The capacity for animals to alter their physiology to better match prevailing environmental conditions, and thereby improve fitness, is known as phenotypic flexibility. As a general rule, birds increase their metabolic rates (a measure of energy use) in response to seasonal increases in energy demand, such as migration or cold winter temperatures. Prominent among the adjustments contributing to flexible metabolic rates in birds are changes in muscle size and the ability to use fats as fuel. Both of these traits tend to increase with increasing energy demand.

The current project examined several key mechanisms that might regulate flexibility of muscle size and fat use in small birds. The studies focused on myostatin, a prominent inhibitor of muscle growth, which has been little studied in wild birds. In this study we: (1) tested whether changes in myostatin levels contributed to adjustments to winter or migration in small birds and (2) attempted to experimentally manipulate myostatin levels to determine the effects on muscle growth and shivering performance. Regarding fat use, we tested whether: (1) seasonal changes in fat transport in muscle cells (since fat is not soluble inside cells) occurred during winter or migration, and (2) changes in fat transport were associated with variation in muscle mass and shivering performance. In addition to these studies, we also examined the relative roles of daylength and temperature in promoting phenotypic flexibility. The overall goals were to characterize potential roles for myostatin and fat transport in regulating seasonal phenotypic flexibility and to determine the environmental cues driving these flexible changes in small birds.

Because the pectoralis muscle is by far the largest muscle in flying birds and plays a major role in both shivering and flight, we focused our studies on the pectoralis. We found that pectoralis muscle size generally increased during winter and migration, as expected. Also consistent with our expectations, myostatin and the proteins that activate myostatin (TLL-1 and TLL-2) generally showed lower levels when the pectoralis muscle enlarged during winter and migration, although this result was not completely consistent across species. This result suggests some among-species variation in the control of the regulation of muscle size. Attempts to block myostatin activity failed to stimulate muscle growth in our studies, despite similar treatments producing muscle growth in mice. This raises the interesting possibility that birds are less sensitive to myostatin than are mammals, but confirmation of this hypothesis will require further research.

Intracellular fatty acid binding protein, which mediates fat transport within the muscle cell, and beta-hydroxyacyl-coA-dehydrogenase, an enzyme that helps control how rapidly fat can be used as fuel, typically increased in pectoralis muscle in winter and migration, suggesting that these are important targets for flexible metabolic responses. However, fat transporters responsible for moving fat across cell and mitochondrial membranes remained mostly unchanged with winter and migration.

Temperature, rather than daylength, was the primary driver of variation in metabolic rates in our studies, and metabolic rates increased in cold-exposed birds.
